content.description: Head up to a rail and negotiate the steep pocket move. Pulling the lip onto the slab above is the crux.
content.location: Left of the "Night Flight" pillar, look for the fixed draw next to a 1-2 finger pocket.

content.description: Start up the center of the slab for 25 ft until the ledge that separates the slab from the upper overhang. After two fun bolts in the overhang, finish up and right.Â
content.location: Center of the East face, left of the (currently) closed projects on the right side of the East face.

content.description: Start up a deceptively steep bolted seam on the left side of the East Wall (shares start with Owls Well That Ends Well). The clip a bolt on the right and wander up and right to the final bolt on the seemingly blank headwall.
content.protection: Bolts with mussies at the anchor.
content.location: Obvious bolted micro seam on the left side of the East Wall. Then finishes right.

content.description: Start up a deceptively steep bolted seam on the left side of the East Wall. Clip a bolt on the left once you are on the slab above and tiptoe up to the final bolt on the headwall above.The crux is working the left arete to crank through to the anchors.
content.protection: Bolts with mussies at the anchor
content.location: Obvious bolted micro seam on the left side of the East Wall. Route then goes left

content.description: A crux boulder problem to gain the second bolt opens up fun low-5.10 climbing above.
content.location: The left route on the lower pillar of the East Face. Shares an anchor with Owlgebraic Formula.

content.description: Start by stemming off of the large detached block to gain a slab, then head up to hidden holds at a small roof.
content.location: The right route on the lower pillar of the East Face. Shares an anchor with Owlometric Equation.

content.description: Face climbing up the left wall's arete from inside the corridor.
content.protection: 3 bolts. Rap anchor or walk off.
content.location: In the East Corridor uphill of the rest of the East Wall routes. This route climbs up the right side of the arete to an anchor with rap rings.

content.description: Starts out with the typical, kind of easy slab for the area. There is a direct start (2 bolts) but the better climbing is to share the start with Too Hoot To Handle. At the ledge/inflection from slab to overhang, this route drifts to the left using underclings in the heuco system. From the huecos, the route moves through somewhat thin holds to exit the roof and a committing move to a good horn on the right. Solid holds above the roof lead to the anchors.
content.location: Left of center on the East face.

content.description: Face climbing to a vertical finish.
content.location: Deep in the East Corridor, uphill of the other East Wall routes.

content.description: Move up the slab and right facing arete following 5 bolts. At the ledge, reach up to clip bolt #6 and move right around the arete using hidden side clings. Work a broad dihedral-type face to access the last bolt while moving back left toward the arete as soon as possible. There is a good looking pocket on the right, beware it is very sharp. It is possible to stay in the right facing corner rather than bust the arete moves, but dirty and way less fun.
content.location: Right side of the East face.

content.description: Start on a steep slab for a few bolts. At the ledge a steep overhang begins and a perma draw is just out of reach. Have no fear, a right hand undercling will allow a 5'7" climber to clip and move on. Work some tricky heel hooks and the arete on the right to reach good (though painfully sharp) pocket on the left. Lever yourself upward and reach good holds above the overhang for an easier finish.
content.location: Right side of the East face.

content.description: Committing but well protected moves up a steep arete. Full value if you avoid punctuating the route by using the small pillar behind you. We will just call the pillar "the comma splice variation" and deduct a few letter grades.
content.location: Obvious arete left of the Corridor, look for the large hueco 2/3 of the way up.

content.description: A variety of grades, from short and pumpy to longer moderates. Sunny on cold spring and fall mornings, but the real highlight is the summer afternoon shade.
